misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Array Index Off-by-One (Treating length as last valid index)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the last element of an array of length n is at index n (and that starting loops at 1 and going to n is interchangeable with Java’s 0..n-1 indexing).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-indexed, so valid indices are 0 to n-1. Accessing arr[n] (or writing to arr[n]) is always out of bounds. Loops written as i=1..n must be translated carefully to 0..n-1 when indexing arrays.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) during the shift step for any n>0

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Incorrect Right-Shift Loop Bounds (Shifting writes past array end)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes shifting from i = n down to 1 will copy elements safely, and that arr[i] exists for i == n.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: A right shift should copy arr[i-1] into arr[i] for i from n-1 down to 1. Starting at i=n attempts to write arr[n], which does not exist. Correct bounds are crucial to avoid overwriting and out-of-bounds access.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when entering the shift loop for any n>0

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that for an array of size 'n', the last valid element can be accessed using the index 'n'.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are zero-indexed, meaning an array of size 'n' has valid indices ranging from 0 to n-1. Attempting to access index 'n' results in an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that while loop counters might need adjustment (using i-1), the direct use of the variable 'n' or the loop index 'i' is appropriate for defining the array's physical boundaries during shifting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student correctly uses 'i-1' in the input and output loops (lines 10 and 23), showing an awareness of zero-indexing. However, they fail to apply this logic to the shifting algorithm, reverting to a model where 'n' is a valid index.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: 1-based array indexing / misunderstanding of Java array bounds
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes Java arrays are indexed from 1 to n, so the last element is at arr[n] and it is valid to assign into arr[n] when shifting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-based: valid indices are 0..n-1. Accessing arr[n] (read or write) is always out of bounds and causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. To get the last element you must use arr[n-1], and when shifting right you must only write to indices 1..n-1 (i from n-1 down to 1).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) during the shift step, so the program never prints the shifted array.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Off-by-one loop boundary for array shifting
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the shifting loop should start at i = n (the 'last position') and shift down to 1, assuming i = n is a valid destination index in the array.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: For an array of length n, the last valid destination index is n-1. The shift-right loop must start from i = n-1 and stop at i >= 1. Starting at i = n attempts to write to arr[n], which does not exist.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when i == n in the shifting loop (even if the earlier arr[n] read were corrected).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that an array of size n has valid indices from 0 to n (inclusive). They treat the array size as if it can be used directly as an index, conflating the size of the array with the last valid index.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, an array of size n has valid indices only from 0 to n-1. The index n is out of bounds. The student appears to not understand that array size and maximum index are offset by 1. At line 26, arr[n] attempts to access index 4 in a 4-element array (indices 0-3), which is invalid.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at runtime when attempting to access arr[n] at line 26

evidence.code_snippet:
for (int i = n; i >= 1; i--) {
    arr[i] = arr[i - 1];

arr[i] = arr[i - 1];
// When i = n, this tries to access arr[n], which is out of bounds

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that for a Java array of size N, the last accessible index is N rather than N-1. While they correctly use (i-1) to map 1-based loop counters to 0-based indices in the input and output phases, they revert to the belief that the index N is a valid memory location during the logic implementation.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are zero-indexed. An array declared with size N has valid indices from 0 to N-1. Any attempt to access index N results in an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. The student correctly handles the total count of elements but fails to apply the 0-indexing constraint to the array's upper boundary during the shifting logic.
